pageData.text: Soil microbes support key <button class='glossary-text'>ecosystem services</button> such as facilitating plant growth, recycling nutrients and organic matter, and regulating air and water quality. Together with plants, microbes regulate the important greenhouse gas, CO<sub>2</sub>. In the Soil Microbial Communities lab, you will analyze how adding different organic materials and fertilizers (substrates) to soil affects soil microbial <button class='glossary-text'>respiration</button> and CO<sub>2</sub> emissions.

pageData.text: Microbial communities and the nutrients available to them can determine the characteristics of an ecosystem. While these microbes themselves are invisible to our eyes, their effects can be seen in which types of plants and animals are able to thrive in each ecosystem, how nutrients are cycled, and, in rare cases, by the vibrant colors they create. Lake Hillier in Middle Island, Australia is a shocking example of the latter. Unlike most lakes, it is not a shade of blue or green but instead is a bright pink, a color entirely determined by the microbes within it. The lake contains species of halobacteria and the algae Dunaliella salina, which are both able to survive in the highly salty water of the lake1. These species produce carotenoid pigments in shades of red and orange, which help them perform photosynthesis in high salinity. In fact, the higher the salinity, the more carotenoids they tend to produce. In addition to lending the pink color to lakes like Lake Hillier, these carotenoids can also move through other organisms in the ecosystem. Algae producing carotenoids can be eaten by shrimp, which are in turn eaten by flamingos, giving both their recognizable pink colors.

1Yarlagadda, T. (2023, March 8). Why are Australia's Pink Lakes Pink? HowStuffWorks Science.
https://science.howstuffworks.com/life/cellular-microscopic/australia-pink-lakes.htm

pageData.subTitle: Soil Microbes
pageData.text: Soil microorganisms are all soil organisms that are <0.1 mm in diameter, and many are singlecelled. They include bacteria, archaea, algae, protists, fungi, and viruses. Of these, bacteria and archaea are both , and all can be found in a very wide variety of environments.Soil microbes are crucial to soil and whole-earth functioning, as they a) recycle nutrients, transforming them into plant-available chemicals, and b) regulate gas exchange between soil and the air (Figure 1).

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A food web diagram shows a series of conversions (represented by arrows) of energy and nutrients as one organism eats another.

pageData.text: Microorganisms found in the soil are taxonomically diverse and play an important role in overall soil function. Note that prokaryotes have simple cell structures, whereas eukaryotes have more complex cell structures featuring organelles.

Soil microbes add to the complexity of soil, which is already complex due to its heterogeneous nature. A single gram of soil contains thousands to tens of thousands of microbe species, and many more species have yet to be discovered. At a distance of even just 1 mm in the soil, an entirely different microbial community maybe present. This is because different microbial communities specialize in growing in different . The main environmental conditions affecting soil microbial growth and the type of microbes are organic substrates, nutrient substrates, aeration, moisture, temperature, pH, and salinity. The presence of toxins may also become important in contaminated soils or when microbes produce toxins to compete with each other. As a result, the diverse environments found in soil select for different microbes. For example, you would expect to find very different organisms adjacent to a dead leaf near the surface of the soil, compared to within a soil aggregate, deep within the soil.

pageData.subTitle: Soil Organic Matter
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Soil organic matter (SOM)</button> is the fraction of soil composed of nonliving organisms in various stages of <button class='glossary-text'>decomposition</button> as well as living soil microbes. This includes decomposing leaf litter, dead roots, decomposing earthworms and insects, and all microorganisms using these components as nutrient sources.

SOM can also be considered the portion of soil that is chemically organic, meaning it contains carbon as C-C and C-H bonds (not to be confused with inorganic C, CO32-). On average, soils contain ~5% organic matter, but young soils and desert soils frequently contain <1%, and wetland soils may contain >30% organic matter. Soils containing >30% organic matter are called .
Soil organic matter has three main components (see Figure 2):
  1. : living microorganisms.
  2. : freshly deposited nonliving organic materials still retaining the shape of the organism they are derived from, such as leaf litter.
  3. : decomposed organic materials that have become amorphous. It no longer resembles the organisms from which they were derived and are typically brown to black and mushy.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Soil organic matter (SOM) is made up 3 main components; microbial biomass, detritus, and humus.

pageData.text: The different components of SOM are continuously transformed into one another via decomposition. Decomposition is the break-down of organic materials into smaller and simpler components. Decomposition can begin as macro- and meso-organisms eat and shred dead plants and animals, breaking them down into smaller pieces. Then microorganisms release enzymes into the soil, helping them break down large organic molecules that are not bioavailable to other organisms into smaller molecules. These smaller molecules are better able to dissolve and then be taken up by plants and microbes.

SOM is essential to soil functioning, and provides or facilitates many by:
  • Storing carbon in the soil, and thereby regulating the climate
  • Facilitating soil aggregation (holding particles together)
  • Increasing soil porosity and water retention
  • Reducing erosion and increasing infiltration
  • Retaining nutrients in soil
  • Providing substrate and nutrients to microbes
  • Mitigating the effects of pollutants through sorption and other mechanisms

pageData.subTitle: Organic Amendments
pageData.text: Given the importance of <button class='glossary-text'>soil organic matter (SOM)</button>, farmers and scientists have a vested interest in learning how to increase the percentage of SOM in soil. This can be increased when the inputs of SOM are greater than the outputs. In a natural system, SOM inputs come from anything that dies in or on the soil, mainly plants and animals. In an agricultural system, SOM inputs would be <button class='glossary-text'>crop residues</button> left on the soil (any parts of the crop that were not harvested) and <button class='glossary-text'>organic amendments</button>. Organic amendments are materials added to the soil derived from living things. This includes mulch (or other plant materials imported from outside the agricultural system), manure, and compost.

pageData.subTitle: Soil Microbial Respiration
pageData.text: To increase percent SOM, land managers can also reduce organic matter outputs, or losses. SOM can be lost from soil via microbial , erosion, or leaching. Of these, soil microbial respiration tends to be the largest loss, followed by erosion. Respiration is a type of oxidation reaction that organisms use to convert organic compounds to energy. Most soil microbes perform using oxygen (O2) as an oxidizing agent (Figure 3), whereas others perform by using other oxidizing agents such as NO3-, Fe3+ or SO42- (and some microbes can perform both). Because aerobic respiration is more efficient, it is the dominant type of respiration in soils with sufficient oxygen (i.e., well-aerated soils). In this investigation, you will estimate soil aerobic respiration following the addition of different amendments to soil. Typically, microbes break down large organic molecules into a combination of soluble sugars and amino acids, which are then used as substrates for respiration. For example, respiration using glucose occurs via the reaction below and as illustrated in Figure 3:C6H12O6 (s) + 6O2 (g) → 6CO2 (g) + 6H2O (l) + energy

pageData.altText: Figure 3: The process by which organisms convert oxygen and sugar into carbon dioxide and energy

pageData.subTitle: Factors Influencing Soil Microbial Respiration
pageData.text: The four main factors influencing the rate of microbial respiration in soils are oxygen concentration, organic carbon (C) substrate concentrations (e.g., sugars), nutrient concentrations (such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium), and <button class='glossary-text'>bioavailability</button> of carbon and nutrients. Other <button class='glossary-text'>environmental conditions</button> influencing microbial growth, such as soil pH and temperature, also affect microbial respiration. The most productive agricultural soils have good aeration; therefore, in these soils, the availability of carbon substrates and nutrients would be the main factors affecting microbial respiration.

Not only does the total amount of organic carbon and nutrients in soil influence soil microbial , but also their . Bioavailability is simply an index of how easily an organism can take up a substance. Generally, more soluble compounds are more bioavailable because they can more easily diffuse through the soil solution and across cell membranes. Smaller, simpler molecules tend to be more bioavailable. For example, sugars are highly soluble, and the carbon in sugars is therefore much more bioavailable than carbon in larger, more complex molecules, like cellulose or lignin. These plant structural molecules are especially complex, and therefore the bioavailability of carbon in cellulose and lignin is very low, and they decompose very slowly.

Concentrations of bioavailable carbon substrates and nutrients do not influence microbial respiration independently, but rather interact. Microbes need both in order to grow, so sufficient carbon is needed for microbes to use nutrients, and sufficient nutrients are needed for microbes to use carbon. Of the nutrients, nitrogen (N) is the most common nutrient limiting both microbial and plant growth. Thus, the of and/or soil organic matter itself is one of the best predictors of microbial respiration, and the ratio is not equal in all decomposing materials (Table 1). The C:N ratio is the concentration of carbon divided by the concentration of nitrogen within a given organic material. Generally, a C:N ratio that is too high will result in lower microbial respiration in the long-term, because microbes do not have enough nitrogen needed to decompose the organic carbon present.

pageData.subTitle: C:N Ratio Influences on Carbon and Nitrogen Cycling
pageData.text: The of substrates not only influences soil microbial but also the amount of nitrogen that plants and microbes can take up. And for all life forms, the forms of nitrogen that are present in nature are not equal, and they cycle through the environment (Figure 4). The two forms of nitrogen that are available to plants are (NH4+) and (NO3-). Microbes can use a greater diversity of nitrogen sources, but these are the most bioavailable due to their high solubility. Note that both NH4+ and NO3- lack C-C or C-H bonds and are therefore (also called “mineral” nitrogen).

pageData.altText: Figure 4: The nitrogen cycle is complex and is largely controlled by various forms of soil microorganisms including nitrogen fixers, nitrifiers, and denitrifiers.

pageData.text:
As microbes decompose organic matter, they break C-N bonds, thereby separating N from the organic molecules in question and converting it to inorganic N (primarily NH4+) in a process called . For example, the mineralization of an amine (found in amino acids) occurs via the general reaction:R-NH2 + nO2 → nCO2 + nH2O + NH4+NH4+ may additionally be oxidized to form NO3-, in a series of 2 oxidation reactions that are together called :
  1. oxidation:
    NH4+ + 1.5O2 → NO2- + 2H+ + 275 kJ energy
  2. Nitrite oxidation:
    NO2- + 0.5O2 → NO3- + 76 kJ energy
The first reaction is performed by ammonium- oxidizing such as Nitrosomonas bacteria, and the second reaction is performed by nitrite-oxidizing prokaryotes such as Nitrobacter bacteria. As evidenced by the energy in the products, these microbes are using the oxidation reactions to get energy.

The H+ in the products indicates that this reaction also acidifies the soil. Usually, nitrite oxidation is much faster than ammonium oxidation (i.e., ammonium oxidation is the rate-limiting step), so the intermediate nitrite (NO2-) is typically used up quickly as long as sufficient oxygen is present. The can be written as:NH4+ + 2O2 → NO3- + H2O + 2H+ + 351 kJ energy

Subsequently, microbes take up <button class='glossary-text'>inorganic nitrogen</button> (NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup> & NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>) from the soil solution and use it to build amino acids and other N-containing organic compounds in a process called <button class='glossary-text'>immobilization</button>. These organic compounds are frequently less soluble and hence less bioavailable than inorganic nitrogen compounds.

Both nitrogen mineralization and immobilization occur continuously in soil, but the of soil amendments influences whether net nitrogen mineralization or immobilization will occur. Soil microbes themselves have C:N ratios ranging from ~8:1 for prokaryotes to ~10:1 for fungi. Some carbon is oxidized into carbon dioxide during , so microbes actually need to consume substrates with higher C:N ratios, ranging between ~15:1 to ~25:1, in order to keep nitrogen mineralization approximately equal to immobilization. In other words, for every 15–25 g of carbon, microbes need approximately 1 g of nitrogen to sustain it.

pageData.subTitle: Streak
pageData.text: Consequently, a soil amendment with a low or “narrow” of less than 15:1 is likely to cause net because excess N is present relative to carbon. This would result in an increase in plant-available nitrogen. A high C:N ratio greater than 25:1 is likely to cause net , resulting in a decrease in plant-available nitrogen. A high C:N ratio results in nitrogen deficiency relative to carbon, causing microbes to use up plant-available nitrogen. In the long term, this lack of nitrogen would also result in reduced microbial growth and .

pageData.subTitle: Using a Respirometer
pageData.text: In this investigation, you will measure the effect of soil amendments with different C:N ratios on soil microbial respiration, inorganic N concentrations, and pH. Activity 1 uses a respirometer to measure the respiration rate of soil samples. The respirometer is composed of a vial containing the soil sample and a volume of air; the mouth of the vial is sealed with a one-hole rubber stopper with a pipet inserted into the hole. To perform the experiment, the entire respirometer is completely submerged in water. If the microbial communities in the soil samples respire, they will use oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>) and release carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>).

Because 1 mole of carbon dioxide is released for each mole of oxygen consumed, there is no change in the volume of gas in the respirometer. However, we can experimentally alter this equilibrium by placing a cotton ball that has been saturated with a solution of potassium hydroxide (KOH) into the bottom of the vial. Potassium hydroxide reacts with carbon dioxide to form potassium carbonate ( K2CO3), which is a solid. The following reaction occurs:CO2 + 2KOH → K2CO3 + H2O
<button class='glossary-text'>Avogadro's law:</button> At constant temperature and pressure, 1 mole of any gas has the same volume as 1 mole of any other gas.

Inside the respirometer, solid K<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> is not observed because it dissolves within the saturated cotton ball as rapidly as it is formed. Therefore, in this experimental setup, cellular respiration consumes oxygen and produces carbon dioxide, which is removed by its reaction with potassium hydroxide, leading to a reduction in the volume of gas inside the submerged respirometer. As the volume of gas inside the vial decreases, water moves from the bath into the submerged pipet. The gas volume decrease is measured from the scale printed on the pipet and can be used to calculate the rate of respiration.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning, collect biologically active soil and prepare a water bath. To start, assemble the respirometers and measure the temperature of the water bath. Measure the mass and volume of the soil samples, add water, and form them into balls. Add sugar to the soil ball for the respirometer labeled simple, and torn leaves or newspaper to the soil ball for the respirometer labeled complex. Add KOH to a cotton ball, add the soil samples to the vials, and seal the respirometers. Add food coloring to the respirometer pipet tips and equilibrate the respirometers in the water bath. If the respirometers have leaks, remove their contents and go back to the KOH step. If not, submerge the respirometers, allow them to equilibrate, then measure the respirometer volumes every 6-8-hours. After 72 hours, determine the change in volume of the respirometers and whether cellular respiration has occurred. Then continue to activity 2.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activity2 of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in activity 2, you will label containers. Then, measure the volume and add the soil. Next, add shredded leaves or newspaper to the containers labeled +C. Then, add ammonium sulfate and cover the vials with parafilm. When all the containers are set up, incubate them in a warm location and record the temperatures daily for 5 days. On day 5, make a calcium chloride solution, add it to the soil samples, and mix. Wait 15-20 minutes, then test the samples with aquarium test strips and with ammonium test strips.

Using the 24 oz deli container from the equipment kit, collect approximately 1 cup of biologically active soil. This sample is the “Collected Soil” sample and will be used in both activities. Before using the sample, remove excess grasses, roots, and other plant materials and break up any large clumps.

Note: If you are unsure if a public location is appropriate to collect a sample from, contact your local Park and Recreation, Fish and Wildlife, State Park, Bureau of Land Management, or National Forest Department.

Note: Biologically active soil can be found near plant roots or anywhere there is decomposing organic matter. Before using the sample, remove excess grasses, roots, and other plant materials and break up any large clumps. You may need to spread the soil out flat to find most of the plant residues. If your soil has a substantial amount (>10% or so) of coarse fragments like gravel or plant debris, you can sieve it with a colander or a sieve.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: A metal colander with handles filled with soil containing excess fragments and a metal bowl filled with a smaller amount of soil that has been strained

typeBefore.title: One day before conducting Activity 1 (1 step)

pageData.text: Prepare a water bath: If using two 9 × 13” pans, fill them both to a depth of approximately 1½” of tap water. If using one larger roasting pan (preferred), fill it to a depth of approximately 1½” of tap water. Allow the water to stand overnight so that it comes to room temperature.
In Activity 1, you will use respirometers to measure the amount of cellular <button class='glossary-text'>respiration</button> being performed by the microbes in various soil samples.
Place one nickel in the bottom of each glass vial.

typeBefore.text:
The following materials are needed:
  • 3 Flat bottom glass vials
  • 3 Nickels
  • 2 Parafilm® squares, 2 × 2”
  • 3 Rubber stoppers with holes
  • 3 Pipets, 1 mL

pageData.text: Take two squares of Parafilm<sup>®</sup> (2 × 2”). Cut each square in half to make two 1 × 2” strips. Use one strip for each of the three respirometers.
To assemble the top of the respirometers, gather one rubber stopper, one 1 mL pipet, and one strip of Parafilm<sup>®</sup>.
Remove the wax paper from a strip of Parafilm® and tightly wrap the strip around one of the pipets, approximately 1½” from the blunt end (Figure 6).

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Experimental setup for constructing a respirometer showing a pipet tip wrapped in Parafilm connected to a stopper; the stopper is then inserted into a glass vial to make the respirometer.

pageData.text: Hold the pipet at the Parafilm<sup>®</sup>, and carefully insert the blunt end of the pipet through the hole in the rubber stopper. This will form an airtight seal.
Hold the pipet as close to the stopper (at the Parafilm<sup>®</sup>) as possible and push carefully.

Take out the water bath that was filled the previous day. The water in the bath will buffer the respirometers against temperature changes and ensures a closed system inside the respirometers during the experiment.

Note: Test if the seal between each stopper and pipet is airtight. After setting up the rubber stoppers and pipets, plug the top of each vial with one of the stoppers, and completely submerge the respirometer in the water bath for 20–30 seconds and check for leakage. If the contact between the stopper and the pipet or the stopper and the vial is leaking, water will begin to enter the vial. Simply tighten the stopper and/or the pipet to correct this. It is better to detect and repair any leaking respirometers at this point before the experiment has begun, to avoid having to repeat the experiment later.
Place a thermometer in the water bath. Check the water temperature 2–3 times over the period of an hour or so before starting the experiment to verify that the temperature is stable.
Label the respirometers, “Blank”, “Simple”, and “Complex”.
Label the weigh boats “Simple” and “Complex”. You will not need a weigh boat for the “Blank”, as this an environmental blank and no soil will be added to the “Blank” respirometer.
Use the digital scale and the “Simple” weigh boat to measure 7 g of your collected soil.
Pour the “Simple” sample into the small plastic cup. Use the measurements on the side to determine what the volume of the soil is. Record your results in Data Table 1.
Wet the soil with water and mix in your hands until soil until forms a ball.
Note: If the soil is too wet and will not form a ball, add more soil. Soil that is a little dry will work for this experiment, but soil that is too wet may interfere with your calculations.
Place the soil ball back onto the weigh boat.
Repeat Steps 3–6 for the “Complex” sample.
Place the “Simple” weigh boat with the soil sample in it and tare the scale.
Add approximately 2 g of sugar to the weigh boat.

Remove the weigh boat from the scale and work the sugar into the soil ball. If the soil ball becomes too dry to stay in a ball, a small amount of water can be added. Once the material is mixed into the soil, place the soil ball back onto the weigh boat.
Place the “Complex” weigh boat with the soil sample in it and tare the scale.
Add approximately 0.2 g of torn newspaper or leaves to the weigh boat.

Remove the weigh boat from the scale and work the leaves or newspaper into the soil ball. If the soil ball becomes too dry to stay in a ball, a small amount of water can be added. Once the material is mixed into the soil, place the soil ball back onto the weigh boat.

Important: It is essential to wear PPE for all subsequent steps of the activity. First, put on the apron, then the protective gloves, and then the safety goggles. Do not proceed to the next step without wearing your PPE.
Place an absorbent cotton ball on top of the nickel in the bottom of each respirometer vial.

typeBefore.text: Caution: Avoid eye and skin contact with the potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution.

pageData.text: Watch this video on how to use a calibrated pipet:

Use a plastic graduated pipet to saturate the cotton with 2.0 mL of 15% potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution. Carefully expel the solution from the pipet to avoid getting KOH on the outside of the glass vials. If KOH does end up on the exterior sides of a vial, dry the vial with a paper towel and dispose of the paper towel in the trash. It is important that the amount of cotton and KOH solution added to the vials are the same for all three respirometers.
Place a small wad of dry, nonabsorbent cotton on top of the KOH-soaked absorbent cotton. This will prevent the soil from being in contact with the KOH solution, which could affect the results.

Place each soil sample into the corresponding labeled respirometers. There will be no soil in the “Blank” respirometer. The purpose of the “Blank” is to measure the CO<sub>2</sub> already in the jar (not produced by microbes). The “Blank” will be compared to the other samples at the end.

Insert a stopper with a pipet into each of the three respirometer vials. The stopper must fit tightly. If any of the respirometers leak during the experiment, the experiment will have to be started over.

Carefully lay the three assembled respirometers on a table or other flat surface without disturbing the moistened cotton ball and soil samples and position the tip of the respirometer pipet over a paper towel. Add some food coloring to the tip of the pipet by hanging a drop of food coloring from a food coloring bottle, so that the drop just touches the tip of the pipet and allow capillary action to pull the drop into the pipet. The food coloring in the pipet will help you observe volume changes in the pipet during the experiment (see Figure 7).

pageData.altText: Figure 7: Food coloring being pulled up into a glass pipet due to capillary action

pageData.text: Note: If you do not have food coloring, water can be used instead. But it may be more difficult to track the movement.
Place the three respirometers into the water bath in an upright position with the pipet tips resting on the lip of the water bath (Figure 8).

pageData.altText: Figure 8: Three respirometers sitting upright in a water bath with the pipet tips resting on the lip of the water bath

pageData.text: If using two 9 × 13” pans, place two respirometers in one bath and one in the other. To submerge the respirometers, angle each so that it lays diagonally in the pan with all respirometers fully submerged.

Allow the respirometers to equilibrate for 5 minutes. This will allow the internal temperature of each vial and its contents to reach thermal equilibrium with the water in the bath and with each other. If any of the respirometers begin to fill with water, there is a leak, and you must start the experiment over.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: After the equilibration period, submerge all the respirometers (including the pipet tips) in the water bath. Position the respirometers so that the scale can be read on each of the pipets. Do not put anything into or take anything out of the water bath until all the necessary measurements have been recorded.

pageData.altText: Figure 9: 3 respirometers with vials and pipet tips fully submerged under water in a water bath.

pageData.text: Allow the respirometers to equilibrate for another 5 minutes, or until the dye (or water) on the respirometer containing the “Simple” has passed the zero mark on the pipet, whichever is later.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: After these equilibrium periods, observe the initial volume reading on the pipet scale of each respirometer to the nearest 0.01 mL. Record this information in Data Table 1 for “Time 0”. Observe and record the temperature of the water bath.

Note: If the dye has not moved into the pipet sufficiently far enough to be able to record the initial volume, mark the location of the dye on the edge of the dye farthest from the tip. In subsequent steps, estimate the change in volume.

Place your samples in a place where they will not be disturbed. You will be measuring the decrease in oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>) gas volume over time. So at first there will be a large bubble in each pipette, and the bubble volume will decrease over time as microbes use up O<sub>2</sub> gas. As the bubble shrinks, water will enter the pipettes from the water bath.

Take observations of the volume on the scale of each respirometer every 6–8 hours, and record this information in Data Table 1. Record the temperature of the water bath for each of the 6–8-hour intervals for 24–72 hours. Each time you take a measurement, also record the temperature.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Note: If your soil samples are extremely active, your dye (or water) will travel very quickly down the pipet, and it may not be necessary to take readings for more than 24 hours. Conversely, if your soil samples are extremely inactive (the gas volume decreases very slowly), you may take readings every 12 hours instead of every 8 hours, for a total of 72 hours.
Use the collected data to perform the calculations necessary to complete Data Table 1.

Note: The volume in the pipet is affected by ambient air pressure. To correct for any pressure changes that occur during the experiment, the change in volume in the “Control” respirometer is subtracted from the change in volume in the “Simple” and “Complex” respirometers. Change in volume = (Volume at time 0) – (Volume at time of current reading) Corrected change in volume = [Change in volume (for “Simple” or “Complex”) - (Change in volume of “Control”)

In Activity 2, you will measure the effect of microbial metabolism and carbon to nitrogen ratios on soil pH, nitrite, and <button class='glossary-text'>nitrate</button>. You will set up soil samples with different amounts of added carbon and <button class='glossary-text'>ammonium</button>, then after 5 days, you will test the pH, nitrite, nitrate and ammonium levels for each soil sample.

pages.title: Cellular Respiration Experiment
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Influence of Microbial Metabolism and C:N Ratios on Soil pH, Nitrite and Nitrate

pageData.text: Obtain 3 specimen cups and 3 lids.
Label the containers “Control”, “Collected Soil”, and “Collected Soil +C”.
You will use the volumetric marking on the side of the specimen cup to put equal amounts of soil in each cup. Record the mass of the soils in Data Table 2.
Place approximately 20 mL of soil in the cup labeled, “Collected Soil”.
Place approximatively 20 mL of soil in the cup labeled “Collected Soil +C”.
Add approximately 1 tablespoon of shredded fresh leaves or newspaper to the “Collected Soil +C” cup.
Use the 10 mL graduated cylinder and measure 4 mL of 1 M ((NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>). Pour the ((NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>) into the “Control” container.
Place lid on the “Control” container.
Cut the Parafilm<sup>®</sup> square into 3 equal pieces.
Wrap 1 piece of the cut Parafilm<sup>®</sup> around the lip of the lid of the container.
Note: Parafilm® is flexible and will stretch around the lid and help ensure that the container is sealed.
Make sure you are wearing your PPE when you are handling the sulfate.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Use the 10 mL graduated cylinder and measure 4 mL of 1 M ((NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>). Pour the ((NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>) into the “Collected Soil” container.

With gloved hands, mix the solution into the soil.
  1. If the soil is still dry, add 1 mL of the ((NH4)2SO4) solution until all particles are wet.
Wrap one piece of the cut Parafilm<sup>®</sup> around the lip of the lid of the container.
Repeat Steps 11–13 for the “Collected +C” sample.
Your samples will need to incubate for 2–4 days in a dark, relatively warm (~70 ºF) location where they will not be disturbed.
Daily record the temperature near the soil samples in Data Table 3.
Record the number of hours that you incubated your control and soil samples in Data Table 2.
Obtain a plastic cup. Use the 100 mL graduated cylinder and measure 100 ml of distilled or spring water and add it to the cup.
Use the digital scale and a weigh boat to measure 5.0 g of calcium chloride.
Add the calcium chloride to the distilled or spring water in the cup.
Stir until the calcium chloride is dissolved in the solution.

Pour the calcium chloride solution into the “Control” sample that has been incubating. The calcium chloride will exchange with adsorbed N (NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup>, NO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup>, and NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>) and flocculate the soil.
Note: Calcium in calcium chloride is a divalent cation that helps soil particles flocculate and settle.
Replace the lid on the container.
Shake the sample intermittently for 1–2 minutes, shaking for 20–30 seconds each time.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Repeat Steps 2–8 for the soil samples. Ensure that during Step 8, the soil has detached from the bottom of jar.
Let the samples sit for 15–20 minutes.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text:
After 15–20 minutes, the soil samples should be completely set on the bottom of the containers. The supernatant (water above the soil) should be clear. If the soil is high in organic matter, it may be tinted and resemble the color of iced tea.
  1. If the supernatant is cloudy (or like tea with milk in it), add 5 grams of calcium chloride directly into the sample and shake for 15–20 seconds. Allow the sample to settle for another 15 minutes.
  2. If the supernatant is still cloudy after the additional 15 minutes, obtain a coffee filter, cup, and funnel from the equipment set. Place the funnel on top of the cup. Place the coffee filter in the funnel. Wet the funnel slightly, so that it will stick to the filter. Slowly pour the supernatant into the filter until you have collected approximately 25–30 mL of the supernatant.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Obtain 3 of the aquarium tests strips (5-in-1 API) from the equipment set.

Carefully dip the first test strip into the supernatant of the “Control” sample. Take care and do not stir up the soil or let the test strip touch the soil.
  1. If you cannot avoid touching the soil, and there is not enough supernatant in the sample, obtain a coffee filter, cup, and funnel from the equipment set. Place the funnel on top of the cup. Place the coffee filter in the funnel. Slowly pour the supernatant into the filter until you have collected approximately 25–30 mL of the supernatant.
Let the test strip sit in the solution for 5–10 seconds, then remove it with color pads facing up. Do not shake off water.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text:
Wait 60 seconds. Then compare test strip colors with the color chart on the aquarium tests strips 5-in-1 bottle. Record pH (fresh water), nitrite (NO2-) and (NO3-) values into Data Table 2.
  1. The 5-in-1 test strips only measure pH down to 6. Soils with pH 6 will show up as 6 on the color scale. Therefore, if your soil pH reads 6, you will need to re-measure the pH with the pH strips.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Obtain 3 ammonium test strips (NH<sub>3</sub>/NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup>).
Dip one test strip in the solution for 5–10 seconds, then remove it with color pads facing up. Do not shake off water.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Wait 60 seconds. Then compare test strip colors with the color chart on the ammonia tests strips bottle. Record ammonia value into Data Table 2.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Repeat Steps 13–18 for the “Collected Soil” and “Collected +C” samples.
Caution: Keep all PPE on during the cleanup.

text: Take the stoppers out of the respirometers and pour the water from the vials down a sink drain. Hold the soil samples with a gloved hand to keep them from falling into the drain.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
Discard the soil into the trash.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
Empty the water from the water bath into the sink and rinse the sink.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
Remove the nonabsorbent cotton, KOH-soaked cotton, and nickel from the vial using a gloved hand. Rinse these items well with water. Dispose of the cotton in the trash.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>

Remove the calibrated glass pipets from each stopper by holding the pipet and Parafilm<sup>®</sup> close to the stopper, and carefully pull the pipet out of the stopper.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>

Wrap the pipets and vials in newspaper, paper bags, or other sturdy paper. Tape the paper securely shut and place it in the trash. Wrapping the glass pipets in paper will prevent anyone who handles the trash from cutting themselves should the glass break.
Dispose of gloves, stoppers, and any remaining disposables in the trash, and wash hands thoroughly.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
Dispose of soil samples in the trash.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
Wash all of the equipment with soap and water.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
Clean and sanitize the work space.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning, collect biologically active soil and prepare a water bath. To start, assemble the respirometers and measure the temperature of the water bath. Measure the mass and volume of the soil samples, add water, and form them into balls. Add sugar to the soil ball for the respirometer labeled simple, and torn leaves or newspaper to the soil ball for the respirometer labeled complex. Add KOH to a cotton ball, add the soil samples to the vials, and seal the respirometers. Add food coloring to the respirometer pipet tips and equilibrate the respirometers in the water bath. If the respirometers have leaks, remove their contents and go back to the KOH step. If not, submerge the respirometers, allow them to equilibrate, then measure the respirometer volumes every 6-8-hours. After 72 hours, determine the change in volume of the respirometers and whether cellular respiration has occurred. Then continue to activity 2.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activity2 of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in activity 2, you will label containers. Then, measure the volume and add the soil. Next, add shredded leaves or newspaper to the containers labeled +C. Then, add ammonium sulfate and cover the vials with parafilm. When all the containers are set up, incubate them in a warm location and record the temperatures daily for 5 days. On day 5, make a calcium chloride solution, add it to the soil samples, and mix. Wait 15-20 minutes, then test the samples with aquarium test strips and with ammonium test strips.

data.title: Aerobic respiration
data.content: The process of cellular respiration that takes place in the presence of oxygen gas to produce energy from food

data.title: Ammonium
data.content: An inorganic nitrogen-containing molecule used by plants as a nitrogen source; chemical formula is NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup> <use subscript on “4” and superscript on “+”>

data.title: Anaerobic respiration
data.content: The process of respiration through which cells can break down sugars to generate energy in the absence of oxygen

data.title: Avogadro's law
data.content: States that at a constant temperature and pressure, 1 mole of any gas has the same volume as 1 mole of any other gas

data.title: Bioavailability
data.content: The proportion of a substance that enters the circulation when introduced into the organism and is so able to have an active effect

data.title: C:N ratio
data.content: The concentration of carbon divided by the concentration of nitrogen within a given organic material

data.title: Crop residue
data.content: Any part of the crop that was not harvested

data.title: Decomposition
data.content: The process of recycling of nutrients that have been used by an organism (plant or animal) to build its body

data.title: Detritus
data.content: Dead organic tissue that has not decomposed

data.title: Ecosystem service
data.content: An output, condition, or process of natural systems that directly benefits or enhances the environment

data.title: Environmental condition
data.content: A state of the environment, including natural resources, soil, surface water, ground water, and air

data.title: Heterogenous
data.content: Of non-uniform composition

data.title: Humus
data.content: Decomposed material that was once part of a living organism

data.title: Immobilization
data.content: The process of microbes using inorganic nitrogen from the environment to build nitrogen-containing molecules in their cells

data.title: Inorganic nitrogen
data.content: The nitrogen atoms that occur in inorganic compounds; the only type of nitrogen usable by plants

data.title: Microbial biomass
data.content: Living microorganisms

data.title: Mineralization
data.content: The process of creating inorganic nitrogen from organic molecules as microbes decompose organic matter

data.title: Nitrate
data.content: An inorganic nitrogen-containing molecule used by plants as a nitrogen source; chemical formula is NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>

data.title: Nitrification
data.content: The process of oxidizing ammonium into nitrate (NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>) through a series of oxidation reactions

data.title: Organic amendment
data.content: Material derived from living things that is added to the soil

data.title: Organic soil
data.content: Soil that has over 30% organic matter

data.title: Prokaryote
data.content: A single-celled organism lacking membrane-bound organelles

data.title: Respiration
data.content: A type of oxidation reaction that organisms use to convert organic compounds to energy

data.title: Soil organic matter (SOM)
data.content: All the organic substances in the soil, both living and dead

data.title: Summary nitrification reaction
data.content: The net reaction describing the 2 oxidation reactions involved in nitrification
